Steep losses in markets in the Middle East this Sunday, losses of around 3-6% in main board benchmarks

8/8

Summary

Market moves yesterday were not about WW III. They were the expected reaction to a crude oil supply shock.

In the coming days we'll see if this narrative changes.

Until then there will be no shortage of these guys

7/8

Given this, the yield move higher makes sense, it was the expected reaction to higher energy prices leading to greater inflation fears.

6/8

This caused short-term inflation breakeven rates to spike.

Restated, the market is pricing in more near-term inflation from higher energy prices.

5/8

What did move yesterday was crude oil. It rose >7%, its biggest day rise since March 2022 (early days of the Ukraine War, 2022's start of WW III ... we seem to have at least one such WW III start a year.)

4/8

So why are we to assume yesterday's start of WW III was THE start of WW III and there should be a massive dollar rally.

Today's WSJ describes it as more like an end than a beginning.

3/8

Do you remember last year's start of WW III?

The events sound familiar ... Israel attacked Iran and Iran retaliated. 

(I'll bet you also forgot WW III also started last year.)

2/8

What is typical when events like happen is we get tables like this.

They are incredibly misleading.

They only highlight known historical events. They don't highlight events that everyone thought was the start of "WW III" but was not.

1/8

Why are we not seeing a "flight-to-quality" into the dollar? Why are bond yields rising?

The answer, I believe, is the markets are NOT viewing Israel/Iran as a safe haven event, but rather a crude oil supply shock story.

IOW, this is NOT viewed as the start of WW III.
